text1: The Trump administration responded quickly to the COVID-19 pandemic.
text2: The administration did not impose national restrictions when it should have.

text1: The Trump administration responded quickly to the COVID-19 pandemic.
text2: The Trump administration did not react quickly enough to counter the economic effects of the pandemic.

text1: The administration acted quickly in shutting down travel from China as they learned more information about the virus.
text2: Some experts see travel bans as ineffective and potentially counterproductive in stopping the spread of viruses.

text1: While unable to prevent the spread of COVID-19 entirely, the travel ban might have slowed the spread early in the pandemic, thus saving lives.
text2: Shutting down travel from China was ineffective at stopping the spread of COVID-19 in the US.

text1: Done early enough, travel bans can delay a virus' spread, buying time for countries to prepare.
text2: Some experts see travel bans as ineffective and potentially counterproductive in stopping the spread of viruses.

text1: The administration provided resources at the request of state officials.
text2: The distribution of the resources of the Strategic National Stockpile was driven by political motivations.

text1: The Trump administration provided a navy ship to help handle COVID-19 patients in New York City.
text2: The ship had very little impact on helping to treat COVID-19 patients. It had a capacity of over 1000 beds, but only treated 182 patients in the month it was there.

text1: The Trump administration dramatically increased the Strategic National Stockpile's resources during the pandemic in order to protect all Americans from health emergencies.
text2: The distribution of the resources of the Strategic National Stockpile was driven by political motivations.

text1: The president should not irresponsibly leverage his position in such an intrusive way.
text2: Trump could have leveraged his position as president to convince states to adopt more responsible policies.

text1: The president should not irresponsibly leverage his position in such an intrusive way.
text2: In cases of emergencies, such as COVID-19, it is ethical for the president to leverage his position so that states make more responsible choices.

text1: Americans often trust their local leaders more than the federal government, which may have lowered compliance.
text2: A strong, centralized response could have prevented unnecessary deaths in some states.

text1: Americans often trust their local leaders more than the federal government, which may have lowered compliance.
text2: American's trust in all levels of government decreased throughout 2020.

text1: Trump declared COVID-19 a national emergency on March 13, 2020, just two days after the WHO labeled it a pandemic.
text2: The administration did not impose national restrictions when it should have.

text1: Poor economic performance and high unemployment occurred across the world during the pandemic. This suggests that Trump is not directly to blame for this phenomenon in America.
text2: The state of the US economy and unemployment rates in 2020 were an indicator that the Trump administration did not handle the COVID-19 pandemic well (p. 1).

text1: Poor economic performance and high unemployment occurred across the world during the pandemic. This suggests that Trump is not directly to blame for this phenomenon in America.
text2: Unlike most major economies, China went all out on lockdowns and reaped the rewards of a growth in GDP during 2020.

text1: The Chinese lockdown method was criticized as inhumane and repressive.
text2: Unlike most major economies, China went all out on lockdowns and reaped the rewards of a growth in GDP during 2020.

text1: Trump also compared the COVID-19 pandemic to a nightmare and war.
text2: Trump made several comments that downplayed the severity of the virus.

text1: Trump also compared the COVID-19 pandemic to a nightmare and war.
text2: As late as June 17, 2020, Trump claimed that the virus was "fading away", even as the US was entering a deadly second wave.

text1: Trump signed the CARES Act, a $2.2 trillion economic stimulus bill, on March 27, 2020, just weeks after the country went into lockdown.
text2: The Trump administration did not react quickly enough to counter the economic effects of the pandemic.

text1: Trump signed the CARES Act, a $2.2 trillion economic stimulus bill, on March 27, 2020, just weeks after the country went into lockdown.
text2: The CARES Act was an insufficient response to the pandemic's economic impact.

text1: The pace and scope of the Trump administration's COVID-19 economic recovery plan was similar to or better than most other countries' plans.
text2: The Trump administration did not react quickly enough to counter the economic effects of the pandemic.

text1: The Trump administration succeeded in overcoming logistical hurdles in America's healthcare system.
text2: The Trump administration did not address the racial inequalities in America's healthcare system when handling the COVID-19 pandemic.

text1: The Trump administration succeeded in overcoming logistical hurdles in America's healthcare system.
text2: The Trump administration failed to manage the equitable distribution of the Strategic National Stockpile.

text1: The US public healthcare system was insufficiently equipped to handle a pandemic before the Trump administration inherited it.
text2: Trump had been in office for three years prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. Therefore, it is his responsibility for not adequately equipping the healthcare system to prepare for such a pandemic.

text1: The US government had identified potential weak points that would emerge during a pandemic but failed to act on them before COVID-19.
text2: It is impossible to be prepared for every conceivable contingency regarding health issues, given limited budgets and the evolution of new diseases.

text1: The US healthcare system had been chronically underfunded for years prior to COVID-19.
text2: If healthcare had been a priority for the Trump administration, this could have been rectified to an extent when Trump took office.

text1: The US healthcare system suffers from structural problems that are deeply entrenched. One presidential term is not enough time to fix them.
text2: This does not mean that efforts cannot be made to fix these problems.

text1: Trump's predecessors had also failed to prepare for a pandemic. Trump was simply continuing their policies and was unlucky that COVID-19 struck during his tenure.
text2: Trump had been in office for three years prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. Therefore, it is his responsibility for not adequately equipping the healthcare system to prepare for such a pandemic.

text1: The decentralization of the US government system made it difficult to implement nationwide policies that could have helped reduce the spread of COVID-19.
text2: The US government has protocols for federal government responses to disasters.

text1: The administration was right to not supersede the bounds of the federal government's constitutional limitations and instead left the COVID-19 response up to the states.
text2: A strong, centralized response could have prevented unnecessary deaths in some states.

text1: Given the differences in case numbers, population, and geography between states, it made sense for each state to set its own rules regarding COVID-19.
text2: Trump wished to override individual state policies to reduce social distancing measures during the COVID-19 pandemic, indicating that such differences were not paramount in his eyes.

text1: Trump was following the precedent set by Woodrow Wilson during the 1918 flu pandemic, in which the White House did not get involved in the states' response.
text2: This was a poor precedent to follow, as the 1918 flu cost over 675,000 American lives.

text1: Americans often trust their local leaders more than the federal government, which may have lowered compliance.
text2: A strong, centralized response could have prevented unnecessary deaths in some states.

text1: Americans often trust their local leaders more than the federal government, which may have lowered compliance.
text2: American's trust in all levels of government decreased throughout 2020.

text1: There are often huge discrepancies between the quality of states' healthcare systems.
text2: Trump could have leveraged his position as president to convince states to adopt more responsible policies.

text1: The president should not irresponsibly leverage his position in such an intrusive way.
text2: Trump could have leveraged his position as president to convince states to adopt more responsible policies.

text1: The president should not irresponsibly leverage his position in such an intrusive way.
text2: In cases of emergencies, such as COVID-19, it is ethical for the president to leverage his position so that states make more responsible choices.

text1: There were no protocols in place for a disaster on the scale of COVID-19.
text2: The US government has protocols for federal government responses to disasters.

text1: No country was prepared for COVID-19, and leaders throughout the world were struggling to come up with effective policies.
text2: The Trump administration failed even in comparison to all these countries and their leaders.

text1: This might be less attributable to Trump and more due to large numbers of Americans ignoring social distancing requirements.
text2: If the death rate of the US under the Trump administration was comparable to that of other G7 countries, there would have been 40% fewer deaths.

text1: Trump authorized Operation Warp Speed to cut red tape in the development of a vaccine.
text2: By naming it "Warp Speed", the Trump administration played into people's fears that the vaccines would be developed too quickly for effective testing, contributing to vaccine hesitancy.

text1: Trump authorized Operation Warp Speed to cut red tape in the development of a vaccine.
text2: Operation Warp Speed also resulted in vaccines being unevenly distributed to wealthy countries, which prolonged the outbreak in poorer countries.

text1: Fixing long-standing racial issues in America's healthcare system would have been too difficult in the middle of a pandemic.
text2: The Trump administration did not address the racial inequalities in America's healthcare system when handling the COVID-19 pandemic.

text1: The Trump administration dramatically increased the Strategic National Stockpile's resources during the pandemic in order to protect all Americans from health emergencies.
text2: The distribution of the resources of the Strategic National Stockpile was driven by political motivations.

text1: It was more important for supplies to be distributed according to need, rather than attempt to distribute them equally everywhere.
text2: The Trump administration failed to manage the equitable distribution of the Strategic National Stockpile.

text1: It is not the Trump administration, but previous administrations, that are responsible for the shortfall in the Strategic National Stockpile.
text2: The Trump administration failed to manage the equitable distribution of the Strategic National Stockpile.

text1: The administration's initial response to the pandemic was based on the information put out by the WHO, which turned out to be misleading.
text2: Trump undermined international organizations such as the World Health Organization, which weakened the US' ability to respond to the crisis globally and in collaboration with other countries.

text1: The WHO came under widespread criticism for not pressing China hard enough on finding answers about the origins of COVID-19.
text2: Trump undermined international organizations such as the World Health Organization, which weakened the US' ability to respond to the crisis globally and in collaboration with other countries.

text1: The WHO came under widespread criticism for not pressing China hard enough on finding answers about the origins of COVID-19.
text2: The WHO defended its relationship with China as necessary to understand COVID-19 in its early stages.

text1: This was done before the COVID-19 pandemic began and would not have been a controversial issue if the virus had not emerged when it did.
text2: The Trump administration disbanded the National Security Councilâ€™s pandemic response team, which could have played a critical role in handling the COVID-19 pandemic.

text1: This was done before the COVID-19 pandemic began and would not have been a controversial issue if the virus had not emerged when it did.
text2: Many scientists were warning that a global pandemic was inevitable before COVID-19 emerged.

text1: The CDC repeatedly released statements and updated data in order to clearly communicate information about the virus.
text2: The Trump administration seems to have discouraged pandemic-related communication from experts in the agencies charged to deal with the response.

text1: The CDC repeatedly released statements and updated data in order to clearly communicate information about the virus.
text2: The CDC's response and updates were very slow, which was out of touch with the needs of the pandemic.

text1: This was necessary in order to prevent the economic consequences of the pandemic from spiraling out of control.
text2: The Trump administration undermined the efforts of scientists and administrators who are responsible for handling the pandemic.

text1: This was necessary in order to prevent the economic consequences of the pandemic from spiraling out of control.
text2: When choosing between harms to the economy and human life, a responsible administration should have chosen to save human lives.

text1: Social distancing policies have a steep cost for the economy. It is understandable that the Trump administration did not want to make any hasty decisions.
text2: When choosing between harms to the economy and human life, a responsible administration should have chosen to save human lives.

text1: Harms to the economy reduce quality of life, which can cost human lives.
text2: When choosing between harms to the economy and human life, a responsible administration should have chosen to save human lives.

text1: Harms to the economy reduce quality of life, which can cost human lives.
text2: When choosing between harms to the economy and human life, a responsible administration should have chosen to save human lives.

text1: Australia's COVID-19 protocols were unnecessarily harsh and forced many families to remain separated for extended periods.
text2: Unlike America, Australia committed to a national lockdown with the goal of eliminating COVID-19. This kept infection rates low and was seen as a successful strategy for much of 2020.

text1: There were other factors that contributed to America's high mortality rate.
text2: This failure contributed to America having one of the highest COVID-19 mortality rates in the world.

text1: There were other factors that contributed to America's high mortality rate.
text2: The presence of other factors does not justify the Trump administration's failure to follow the advice of health officials.

text1: The advice of scientists was often confused and conflicting early in the pandemic.
text2: The Trump administration failed to follow the advice of scientists and health experts.

text1: The advice of scientists was often confused and conflicting early in the pandemic.
text2: It was inevitable that guidelines would change as scientists became more knowledgeable about the virus. However, the Trump administration continued to undermine scientists throughout the pandemic.

text1: Health authorities experimented with several potential treatments for COVID-19, many of which were later rejected.
text2: It is natural for different treatment options to be explored, and for many to not be viable, when a novel disease spreads among people.

text1: The US CDC originally said that masks were not needed to prevent the spread of COVID-19, before reversing this policy in April 2020.
text2: Due to the shortage of masks early in the pandemic, it was deemed necessary to make sure that healthcare workers had adequate supplies before promoting mask use in the general population.

text1: The US CDC originally said that masks were not needed to prevent the spread of COVID-19, before reversing this policy in April 2020.
text2: Even when the CDC recommended mask-wearing, Trump disagreed with these instructions.

text1: There were non-scientific considerations that had to be taken into account while making decisions pertaining to the pandemic.
text2: The Trump administration failed to follow the advice of scientists and health experts.

text1: There were non-scientific considerations that had to be taken into account while making decisions pertaining to the pandemic.
text2: While this may be true, a compromise should be sought in such cases. Trump outright ignored scientific facts.

text1: Social distancing policies have a steep cost for the economy. It is understandable that the Trump administration did not want to make any hasty decisions.
text2: When choosing between harms to the economy and human life, a responsible administration should have chosen to save human lives.

text1: Harms to the economy reduce quality of life, which can cost human lives.
text2: When choosing between harms to the economy and human life, a responsible administration should have chosen to save human lives.

text1: Closing borders can be tricky, as it may offend other countries.
text2: Choosing not to close borders can also be offensive, as in the case of the US-Canada difference in opinion regarding whether or not cross-border travel should be resumed.

text1: International relations are important for the security and stability of a country.
text2: The US's international image suffered greatly as a result of their poor policies under Trump during the COVID-19 pandemic,

text1: Trump also compared the COVID-19 pandemic to a nightmare and war.
text2: Trump made several comments that downplayed the severity of the virus.

text1: Trump also compared the COVID-19 pandemic to a nightmare and war.
text2: As late as June 17, 2020, Trump claimed that the virus was "fading away", even as the US was entering a deadly second wave.

text1: Several members of the Trump administration publicly acknowledged that COVID-19 was a serious disease.
text2: The administration continued to reinforce the idea that COVID-19 was not serious to the public.

text1: Several members of the Trump administration publicly acknowledged that COVID-19 was a serious disease.
text2: As Trump himself did not support this position, the remarks of other administration members were often discredited in the eyes of Trump's followers.

text1: Social distancing policies have a steep cost for the economy. It is understandable that the Trump administration did not want to make any hasty decisions.
text2: Countries that responded to the pandemic earlier were able to contain the spread of the virus more effectively.

text1: Social distancing policies have a steep cost for the economy. It is understandable that the Trump administration did not want to make any hasty decisions.
text2: When choosing between harms to the economy and human life, a responsible administration should have chosen to save human lives.

text1: Harms to the economy reduce quality of life, which can cost human lives.
text2: When choosing between harms to the economy and human life, a responsible administration should have chosen to save human lives.

text1: Working from home often required the use of new technologies that some companies were not equipped to handle right away.
text2: The administration could have implemented a work from home order earlier in the pandemic.

text1: Due to the shortage of masks early in the pandemic, it was deemed necessary to make sure that healthcare workers had adequate supplies before promoting mask use in the general population.
text2: The administration should have made recommendations to the country to be cautious (wear masks, social distance, etc...) during the earlier stages of the virus.

text1: Unlike many Asian countries, the US doesn't have a mask wearing culture. If the administration had recommended masks early in the pandemic, it is unlikely that many people would have complied.
text2: The administration should have made recommendations to the country to be cautious (wear masks, social distance, etc...) during the earlier stages of the virus.

text1: Unlike many Asian countries, the US doesn't have a mask wearing culture. If the administration had recommended masks early in the pandemic, it is unlikely that many people would have complied.
text2: Trump went out of his way to mock mask wearers. This likely led to a higher level of resistance to mask wearing among his supporters.

text1: The CDC repeatedly released statements and updated data in order to clearly communicate information about the virus.
text2: The Trump administration seems to have discouraged pandemic-related communication from experts in the agencies charged to deal with the response.

text1: The CDC repeatedly released statements and updated data in order to clearly communicate information about the virus.
text2: The CDC's response and updates were very slow, which was out of touch with the needs of the pandemic.

text1: The CDC began publishing information about the novel coronavirus on their website on January 10, 2020, which was a very early stage in the outbreak.
text2: The administration should have been more transparent about the virus in the early-stages of its spreading.

text1: The CDC began publishing information about the novel coronavirus on their website on January 10, 2020, which was a very early stage in the outbreak.
text2: Most people don't read the CDC website regularly. The administration could have more actively promoted awareness of the disease at this time.

text1: The US has a population size of 333 million. In March 2020, the CDC website was viewed 1,075,594,920 times. This indicates that a lot of people were reading their website.
text2: Most people don't read the CDC website regularly. The administration could have more actively promoted awareness of the disease at this time.

text1: The administration conducted daily media briefings with health experts early in the pandemic.
text2: The Trump administration failed to adequately communicate the risks associated with COVID-19.

text1: The administration conducted daily media briefings with health experts early in the pandemic.
text2: These briefings were often full of misinformation, such as that UV light or disinfectants could be an effective way to rid the body of COVID-19.

text1: The administration conducted daily media briefings with health experts early in the pandemic.
text2: Trump eventually had to discontinue these daily media briefings due to several factors, such as internal party pressure, brought on by how problematic the media briefings had become.

text1: The briefings were a huge ratings hit, meaning that much of America was able to get direct information related to the pandemic.
text2: Some of these briefings were incoherent, overly ostentatious and irrelevant.

text1: Trump's comments about ingesting disinfectants were largely taken out of context by the media.
text2: These briefings were often full of misinformation, such as that UV light or disinfectants could be an effective way to rid the body of COVID-19.

text1: Trump took a number of important measures to communicate the risk at the appropriate time.
text2: The Trump administration failed to adequately communicate the risks associated with COVID-19.

text1: Trump took a number of important measures to communicate the risk at the appropriate time.
text2: Trump was considered the biggest hurdle to proper precautions being communicated to the public, as he was one of the biggest sources of misinformation.
